title: Handling of cells outside of viewport
question_body:
Testing #223152

1) select two cells
2) scroll the lower cell (cell 2) out of the viewport
3) cmd+/ 
4) scroll cell 2 partially into the viewport -> only cell 1 has been commented
5) cmd+/ -> cell 1 has been uncommented, cell 2 has been commented

After step 3 I'd expect both cells to be commented and after step 5 both to be uncommented
first_answer_body:
Need to move the toggle comments action off of the editor command. Case is simpler overall since we are not operating on cursors or a specific selection. 

Relying on `editor.executeCommands()` is the limitation, as we don't have editors outside of the viewport. We can construct these edits in a similar way to a `LineCommentCommand` and simply apply them to the model, allowing us to apply to cells outside of the viewport

title: Add matrixParamsHandling to the router

### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

router

### Description

There are options for preserving query params and fragments but not for matrix params.

### Proposed solution

Be consistent and add `matrixParamsHandling`:

```ts
this.router.navigate(['.', { foo: 'bar' }], {
   matrixParamsHandling: 'merge'
})
```

We need to do it manually now.

title: Merge script to warn in case `feat` commits are present before merging into a patch branch
question_body:
# 🚀 Feature request

### Description
When merging PRs with multiple commits it's easy to miss a `feat` commit that may go into a patch branch accidentally. Since only `dev-infra` feature commits are allowed in patch branch, it'd be great to check all commits that are about to be merged to patch branch and warn caretaker in case there is a `feat` commit with a scope other than `dev-infra`.

// cc @josephperrott @devversion
first_answer_body: Great suggestion. We'd need to play with how it can work for the autosquash and Github API merge strategy. Most likely it should be part of the label configuration, where each label has something like a `validate` hook (that might even work nicely with validations we have for branches)

title: Verify breaking changes note presence before merging a PR
question_body:
# 🚀 feature request

For PRs that contain the "breaking changes" flag, it'd be great to have a check that would make sure that at least one commit has a message that contains the "BREAKING CHANGE" note (in a format compatible with the change log generation script). That should make sure that there are no breaking changes merged without adding the necessary note to the change log.

Given the fact that the "breaking changes" flag might be assigned after CI has completed, having the check in the `lint` job might not be sufficient, so it looks like the merge script is the best location. We can probably have both though (the `lint` job as well as the merge script) to provide feedback to a developer early.

title: Ivy LS: autocompletion TCB fixture for top-level expression context
question_body:
Autocompleting in a top-level context (e.g. completing at `{{|}}`) is challenging, because it merges several different namespaces. The user could be attempting to refer to a component property, a variable defined at the current template level or above, a template reference (again at the current level or above), or certain "special" identifiers like `$any`. In event contexts, they might also be referring to the `$event` variable.

The compiler should offer an API to complete a top-level context expression, independently of template position, to allow the LS to provide an autocompletion experience in such contexts.

title: angular-bot should add "merge" label, when "merge-assistance" label is added
question_body:
currently if anyone adds "PR action: merge-assistance" label to a PR and forget to add also "PR action: merge" label, the caretaker often misses these PRs because they filter only by the latter label and github doesn't support OR operator for queries.

to fix this common problem, the robot should automatically add the "PR action: merge" label if "PR action: merge-assistance" label was added but "PR action: merge" label is missing.

title: ngc translation merging chokes on messages (from other frameworks) that it can't parse
question_body:
The XMB/XTB can potentially contain messages that have not been added by Angular extraction in cases there are multiple frameworks that add to the messages in the XMB.

For ex. ngc chokes on the following message that has been added by a different framework because of the {{REGION_COUNT 2}...}.

<msg id="1185030469700784449" desc="[ICU Syntax] Some message">{REGION_COUNT_1,plural, =0{unused plural form}=1{1 region}other{{REGION_COUNT_2} regions}}</msg>


**I'm submitting a ...**  (check one with "x")
```
[X] bug report => search github for a similar issue or PR before submitting
[ ] feature request
[ ] support request => Please do not submit support request here, instead see https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#question
```

**Current behavior**
ngc message merging fails with an error

**Expected behavior**
ngc is successfully able to merge translations without errors
first_answer_body:
The issue here is that Angular does not support referencing variables as `REGION_COUNT_2` in `{{REGION_COUNT_2} regions}}`. The way to do this in Angular would be to use an interpolation.

Because g3 xmb contain extraction from both soy templates and angular templates, we have to make sure that any construct used in soy templates can be parsed by angular even if angular will not be able to deal with that particular syntax.

The fix is to add an `ICU_REF` token to the lexer/parser. Expect the fix to land sometime next week.

title: github bot: mark PRs with a google3 status
question_body:
@ocombe here's how it should work:

whenever a PR has the merge label applied, or a new SHA is pushed to a PR with the merge label
1) get the head SHA
2) if that sha has no status with google3 context, then 
  a) if the PR affects any of these files
```
include = [
        "BUILD.bazel",
        "LICENSE",
        "WORKSPACE",
        "modules/**",
        "packages/**",
    ],
    exclude = [
        "packages/language-service/**",
        "**/.gitignore",
        "**/.gitkeep",
    ],
```
 then push a `'{"state":"pending", "context":"google3", "description": "Verifying this change in google3"}'` status to it
   b) otherwise push a `{"state":"success", "context":"google3", "description": "Does not affect google3"}` status to it
first_answer_body: @alexeagle should we do that even if the merge label is applied but some other tests are failing? (travis, pullapprove, labels, ...?)

title: Router - replace history instead of pushing
question_body:
**I'm submitting a ...**  (check one with "x")

```
[ ] bug report
[x] feature request
[ ] support request => Please do not submit support request here, instead see https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#question
```

**Current behavior**

Currently there is no way to use history.replace within router.

**Expected/desired behavior**

Need to introduce option for router to replace a history instead a pushing a new.

**What is the motivation / use case for changing the behaviour?**

For example Im in a question list (`/questions`) opening a new modal in a new route (`/questions/add`), and after adding a new question I go to the question view (`/questions/1`). If I press back I would like to go to the `/questions` instead of `/questions/add`

**Please tell us about your environment:**
- **Angular version:** 2.0.0-rc.5
- **Browser:** [all] 
- **Language:** [all]
first_answer_body:
I think support for this is coming, looking at the source in master - https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/modules/%40angular/router/src/router.ts

It looks like the syntax will be 

``` typescript
this.router.navigate(['some/url'], { replaceUrl: true }); 
```

Looks like @brandonroberts did the work on this, he might be able to confirm if the above is correct.

title: Need a tool to migrate the code by the 3.0.0 release
question_body:
Most of the breaking changes in future major releases will be announced in advance and users will still be able to use the former (deprecated) API giving them time to adapt their code before the next major release when the deprecated APIs will be removed.

However in some cases this is not possible and we should provide a tool to migrate user apps for those.

See most of the PR in https://github.com/angular/angular/pulls?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Apr+label%3A%22flag%3A+breaking+change%22

For example narrowing down return types (from any to something, by adding generics, ...)
first_answer_body:
We do have a tool, tslint -f applyFixes.
However, I doubt that it is expressive enough to accomplish all the needed
refactorings, and also we want to package it differently (ng update 3.0.1
or something).

I recommend that we start by merging the breaking changes into google3,
using a tslint refactoring, then we just need to package the tslint command
for external users when we cut the first ng3 release.

title: Add support for physical hard disks
question_body:
While this is something that HyperV supports, if I set it on the VM itself, Docker breaks basically. I had to delete the VM and let docker create a new one.

I have an "unused" SSD in my computer, and I would like to pass it through directly to the VM to increase IO performance.
first_answer_body:
Hello,

This is the first time I see this request. Could you point to any documentation benchmarking the perf difference between using directly an SSD as VM disk and using a vhdx file on a actual SSD ?

a -v flag, to be on par with the Linux variant,
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/125067

STEPS:

please see

title: kubelet: cadvisor supports enable network tcp metrics
question_body:
### What would you like to be added?

Some of our customers want the TCP-related metrics from the cadvisor.
- kubelet ignores these metrics by default.

Option:
1.  Add a kubelet config option in KubeletConfiguration. If it is enabled, add NetworkTcpUsageMetrics in the included metrics list of cadvisor.
2. Make a general config to config more Metrics to add. 
The list can be found at https://github.com/google/cadvisor/blob/d569a2a47baa73c489d7138afb2c0745769c8791/container/factory.go#L48-L69.
The default list should be kept always.
https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/blob/442574f3a7321ff0f34dec9bae67f28651dbabd2/pkg/kubelet/cadvisor/cadvisor_linux.go#L86-L104


Workaround:
- If you need TCP-specific metrics, you can [run a daemonset](https://github.com/google/cadvisor/tree/master/deploy/kubernetes) with [tcp metrics enabled](https://github.com/google/cadvisor/blob/master/docs/runtime_options.md#metrics). See https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/issues/60279#issuecomment-469360637.



### Why is this needed?

https://github.com/google/cadvisor/blob/master/docs/storage/prometheus.md

/sig instrumentation
/sig node
/cc @dashpole 
For disable process metrics, we have some discussions in https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/107660 and https://github.com/kubernetes/kubernetes/pull/107630. This is another topic of enabling some more metrics.
first_answer_body:
cc @bobbypage

We might not want to do this given the in-progress migration from cAdvisor to CRI-based stats.  This would increase the surface area of things that would need to be migrated

title: e2e: use DeferCleanup for Framework instance
question_body:
### What would you like to be added?

The following code is slightly wrong:

```
f := framework.NewDefaultFramework("foo")

AfterEach(func() {
   // do something with f.ClientSet
})
```

It's wrong because f.AfterEach runs first and clear f.ClientSet.

We can make such code work as intended by switching to `DeferCleanup` as discussed in https://github.com/onsi/ginkgo/issues/1022.

### Why is this needed?

Not being able to use the framework instance at the same nesting level is not obvious (causing developers to loose time while debugging a non-working test - been there, done that...) and the workaround (extra Context calls) isn't nice (extra space in test name, more indention).

title: Cert-manager and Ingress pods in Crash loop back off (AKS)
question_body:
I was trying to upgrade the kubernetes version of our cluster from 1.19.7 to 1.22 and some of the worker nodes failed in updating so I restarted the cluster. After restarting the upgrade was successful but Cert-manager-webhook and Cert-manager-cainjector pods went down along with the ingress pods. i.e. they are either in crashloopbackoff state or error state

after checking the logs, these are the errors that I see,

**The cert-manager-webhook is throwing this error - "msg"="Failed to generate initial serving certificate, retrying..." "error"="failed verifying CA keypair: tls: failed to find any PEM data in certificate input" "interval"=1000000000
"msg"="Generating new ECDSA private key"**

**The cert-manager-cainjector is throwing this error- cert-manager/controller-runtime/manager "msg"="Failed to get API Group-Resources" "error"="an error on the server ("") has prevented the request from succeeding"**

**The nginx-ingress pod is throwing this error - SSL certificate chain completion is disabled (--enable-ssl-chain-completion=false)**

Can anyone please help?

Thank you.
/sig k8s-infra

title: kubernetes cluster failed to start after reboot the computer
question_body:
### What happened?

kubernetes cluster failed to start after reboot the computer

title: Scheduler: Ensure the default config output of --write-to-config is usable
question_body:
--write-to-config flag in the scheduler writes to a file the default component config; however this config if passed back to the scheduler is not usable because it lists all default plugins as enabled without disabling them.

To make the configuration usable as an input config while at the same time useful for debugging, the output should disable all plugins for each extension point using the "*" expression.

title: Switching to a mode of transport for which a path exists does not return a path
question_body:
When a user selects a path between two points for which there is no path by car and then uses the drop down to select walking then the message "Couldn't find a route between those two places." will still be displayed, even though a path exists for walking. 

Steps for reproduction:

1. Open https://www.openstreetmap.org/directions?engine=graphhopper_car&route=58.924%2C43.726%3B50.062%2C19.937
2. As you can see there is no path by car which connects these two points.
3. Use the dropdown in the top left corner to select any walking directions.
4. Observe the message "Couldn't find a route between those two places."
5. Press the blue "Go" button and notice that a path by foot does in fact exist.
first_answer_body: Using the link you provided graphhopper and OSRM both found a route for walking. It's possible that the new route had not been imported into graphhopper or OSRM when you did your tests.

title: `ER_INVALID_VYLOG_FILE` error isn't ignored in `force_recovery` mode
question_body: We've encountered quite a few bugs when recovery failed because of a logically invalid vylog record: #10277, #10128, #5436, #4066, #3416. Bugs like those are quite severe because there's no easy for the user to recover data. We should let the user recover from a broken vylog by setting the `force_recovery` flag. At worst, they'll lose a chunk of data but it's still better than loosing all the data. BTW in all the bugs enumerated above, ignoring the invalid vylog records wouldn't result in any data loss - at worst, a garbage run file on disk would never be removed.
first_answer_body: Note that a vylog is recovered not only at startup, but also on snapshot, garbage collection, and backup. We probably need to forward the `force_recovery` flag there as well.

title: cli: the -i option is ignored in some cases
question_body:
**Bug description**

The `-i` option is ignored in some cases.

**Tarantool version:**
- Tarantool 3.2.0-entrypoint-112-g319357d59

**Example:**
It works correctly in the following case:
```
./src/tarantool --name instance-001 --config doc/examples/config/single.yaml -i
```

However, it doesn't work in this case:
```
./src/tarantool --name instance-001 --config doc/examples/config/single.yaml -l yaml <(echo "print(yaml.encode(box.info))") -i
```
In the second case it outputs:
```
2024-07-03 11:02:45.301 [617605] main I> entering the event loop
```
**Expected  behavior (second case):**

The `-i` option should enable interactive mode.

=========
*__from notion__*
first_answer_body: This issue arises due to the behavior of `getopt_long`. In the second case, the `-i` option appears after the argument `<(echo "print(yaml.encode(box.info))")`, which is not an option. Therefore, the parser concludes that the list of options has ended and stops processing further options.

title: Update quorum in `on_commit` trigger instead of `on_replace` trigger.
question_body: For addition of new replicas, let's update the quorum in the `on_commit` trigger. This way we’ll be able to insert a node regardless of the current configuration. This contradicts with the Raft specification, which requires application of all configuration changes in the `on_replace` trigger (i.e., as soon as they are persisted in the WAL, without quorum confirmation).
first_answer_body:
This is a bugfix and we should backport it to 2.11 and 3.1:

On 2.11 the user is able to make space `_cluster` synchronous manually, and usually does so to avoid split-brain when mixing synchronous and asynchronous replication. If this is the case, without this ticket fixed the users on 2.11 may face a situation where they cannot add a new replica to a working cluster: for example, adding a 4th node to a 3-node cluster when only 2 of the nodes are alive will fail, because master will believe that the quorum is 3, while the replica being joined won't ack its own insertion due to how our join protocol works.

title: box.execute no longer can be used to query since 3.x?
question_body:
**Bug description**

A clear and concise description of what the bug is.

* OS: Linux
* OS Version: Pop!_OS 22.04/Ubuntu
* Architecture: amd64

tarantool run using docker-compose

Place `tarantool --version` output here.
```
Tarantool 3.1.0-0-g96f6d88597
Target: Linux-x86_64-RelWithDebInfo
Build options: cmake . -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/tarantool/static-build/tarantool-prefix -DENABLE_BACKTRACE=TRUE
Compiler: GNU-8.3.1
C_FLAGS: -fexceptions -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -static-libstdc++ -fno-common -msse2  -fmacro-prefix-map=/tarantool=. -std=c11 -Wall -Wextra -Wno-gnu-alignof-expression -fno-gnu89-inline -Wno-cast-function-type -O2 -g -DNDEBUG -ggdb -O2
CXX_FLAGS: -fexceptions -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -static-libstdc++ -fno-common -msse2  -fmacro-prefix-map=/tarantool=. -std=c++11 -Wall -Wextra -Wno-invalid-offsetof -Wno-gnu-alignof-expression -Wno-cast-function-type -O2 -g -DNDEBUG -ggdb -O2
```

**Steps to reproduce**

Run two tarantool instances iteractively.

1. create space "users" with any fields
2. box.execute [[ SELECT * FROM "users" ]]

**Actual behavior**

```
 box.execute [[ SELECT * FROM "users" LIMIT 1 ]]
---
- null
- Scanning is not allowed for 'users'
...
```

**Expected behavior**

can query like normal
first_answer_body:
All scanning queries (even with limit) raise an error without [SEQSCAN](https://www.tarantool.io/en/doc/latest/how-to/sql/sql_tutorial/#the-seqscan-keyword) keyword. It is needed to avoid accidental scans. If you don't like it, you can disable it for current session with `SET SESSION "sql_seq_scan" = true;` or for all sessions with `compat` [option](https://www.tarantool.io/en/doc/latest/reference/reference_lua/compat/sql_seq_scan_default/).

P.S. SEQSCAN wasn't required in Tarantool 2.x because the combat option is set to `old` there.

It's expected behavior, so I'm closing the issue.

title: `json.encode/decode` incorrect check optional cfg
question_body:
```
tarantool> cfg = nil
---
...

tarantool> require("yaml").encode({}, cfg)
---
- '--- []

  ...

  '
...

tarantool> require("yaml").decode("{}", nil)
---
- {}
...

tarantool> require("json").encode({}, cfg)
---
- error: attempt to index a nil value
...

tarantool> require("json").decode("{}", cfg)
---
- error: attempt to index a nil value
...

tarantool>
```



```
Tarantool 2.11.2-0-g1bac2d2
Target: Linux-x86_64-Release
Build options: cmake . -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/home/linuxbrew/.linuxbrew/Cellar/tarantool/2.11.2 -DENABLE_BACKTRACE=TRUE
Compiler: /usr/bin/clang /usr/bin/clang++
C_FLAGS: -fexceptions -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fno-common -fopenmp -msse2 -Wformat -Wformat-security -Werror=format-security -fstack-protector-strong -fPIC -fmacro-prefix-map=/tmp/tarantool-20231208-6277-sitw2s/tarantool-2.11.2=. -std=c11 -Wall -Wextra -Wno-gnu-alignof-expression -fno-gnu89-inline -Wno-cast-function-type
CXX_FLAGS: -fexceptions -funwind-tables -fasynchronous-unwind-tables -fno-common -fopenmp -msse2 -Wformat -Wformat-security -Werror=format-security -fstack-protector-strong -fPIC -fmacro-prefix-map=/tmp/tarantool-20231208-6277-sitw2s/tarantool-2.11.2=. -std=c++11 -Wall -Wextra -Wno-invalid-offsetof -Wno-gnu-alignof-expression -Wno-cast-function-type
```
first_answer_body:
Yaml `encode()` has no second argument according to the [doc](https://www.tarantool.io/en/doc/latest/reference/reference_lua/yaml/#index), so the direct comparison is not valid.
As for dedicated `cfg()` interface they do behave exactly the same:
```
tarantool> require('json').cfg(nil)
---
- error: 'bad argument #2 to ''?'' (table expected, got nil)'
...

tarantool> require('yaml').cfg(nil)
---
- error: 'bad argument #2 to ''?'' (table expected, got nil)'
...
```

title: ER_PROTOCOL in relay when replicating transactions with last local row
question_body:
**Bug description**

Replication is broken on replica reconnect if master writes transactions where last row is local while the replica doesn't follow.

Tarantool version:

**Steps to reproduce**

Run two tarantool instances iteractively in clean directories.
```lua
-- Instance 1.
-- Step 1.
box.cfg{listen=3301}
box.schema.user.grant('guest', 'replication')
box.schema.space.create('glob'):create_index('pk')
box.schema.space.create('loc', {is_local=true}):create_index('pk')

-- Step 4.
box.begin() box.space.glob:replace{1} box.space.loc:replace{1} box.commit()
box.space.glob:replace{2}

-- Instance 2.
-- Step 2.
box.cfg{replication=3301}
-- Step 3.
box.cfg{replication=""}

-- Step 5.
box.cfg{replication=3301}
```
After step 5 replication won't start. Logs on both instances will contain the following error:
```
ER_PROTOCOL: Found a new transaction with previous one not yet committed
```
And `box.info.replication` on replica will show
```
tarantool> box.info.replication
---
- 1:
    id: 1
    uuid: 5b636832-905c-4ed3-98cc-5d17448a3ccf
    lsn: 6
    upstream:
      peer: '3301'
      lag: 0.00042891502380371
      status: stopped
      idle: 686.26692
      message: Found a new transaction with previous one not yet committed
  2:
    id: 2
    uuid: fc8d7386-bd1b-43e0-98db-4fd2edadb91d
    lsn: 0
...
```
first_answer_body:
Caused by #9032: after the fix, the logic described along the lines https://github.com/tarantool/tarantool/blob/51ed892c5b63673ccae99f731cbc772b54749e2e/src/box/box.cc#L4658-L4674
became wrong: previously skipping all the local rows didn't break transaction boundaries, because the transactions always ended with a global row (at least a NOP), recovery couldn't miss the transaction end flag, because it was in a global row, which's never skipped.

Now this isn't true. We intentionally removed the NOPs.

The possible solution I see is to make recovery subsystem (it feeds the rows one-by-one to relay and local recovery) aware about transactions. It should either skip all the rows of the transaction (in case it needs neither of them) or pass all of them to the next layer (even the local ones).

title: [svacer] `sym_hdr.sh_entsize` must be tested to be zero before division
question_body:
Svacer [link](https://svacer.tarantool.io/mode/review/project/9ae45b10-738c-4bca-b373-1a40a2646c6c/branch/3d7c9327-519e-45f4-9733-8f8bf5e1b384/snapshot/9aececf2-bf6f-4dca-9f83-364b301fbaa6/filter/eyJ3YXJuQ2xhc3MiOlsiRElWSVNJT05fQllfWkVSTy5FWC9DWFgiXX0=/marker/eyJtYXJrZXJJRCI6IjJiOTRlODQ1LTYwNTItNDFkYy05NjM1LTYzODkyMWNjNmJmYSIsImZpbGUiOiIvdGFyYW50b29sLXNkay90YXJhbnRvb2wtMy4wL3RhcmFudG9vbC90aGlyZF9wYXJ0eS9sdWFqaXQvc3JjL2xqX3N5bXRhYi5jIn0=)
Relevant code: [LuaJIT](https://github.com/tarantool/luajit/blob/fef60a1052b8444be61e9a9932ab4875aff0b2ed/src/lj_symtab.c#L200-L213)
As I see at `dump_sht_symtab` we validate many aspects of the input `ELF` file, therefore it would be good to validate this point too.
first_answer_body:
From `man 5 elf`:
```
 sh_entsize
              Some sections hold a table of fixed-sized entries, such as
              a symbol table.  For such a section, this member gives the
              size in bytes for each entry.  This member contains zero
              if the section does not hold a table of fixed-size
              entries.
```

The section in question is `SHT_SYMTAB`, and, as one can clearly see above, it is specifically pointed out in the manpage that this section has fixed-size entries, so `sh_entsize` must be non-zero.

One can argue that the ELF file itself can be malformed, but while taking that argument into consideration, we should also remember that the `dump_sht_symtab` function only processes ELF files that have already been loaded into our runtime. So considering that this ELF file has already been successfully loaded, it must be valid.

With that in mind, this issue should be considered a false positive.
